questions.question: He insisted ……………… paid at once.
questions.description: After a verb + preposition, we normally use the –ing form of the following verb.

questions.question: I don’t like the idea ………………….. old.
questions.description: After a noun + preposition, we usually use the –ing form of the following verb.

questions.question: I am not very good …………………..
questions.description: After an adjective + preposition, we usually use the –ing form of the following verb.

questions.question: I was interested .....................… that my ancestors were from Burma.
questions.description: We use an infinitive after learn to talk about successfully learning something.

questions.question: I don’t think they mean ………………….. for the moment.
questions.description: When ‘mean’ means ‘intend’, it is followed by an infinitive.

questions.question: If you want to pass the test that will mean …………………. hard.
questions.description: When ‘mean’ means ‘involve’, it is followed by an –ing form.

questions.question: I’m beginning ………………… things better.
questions.description: Infinitives are preferred after continuous forms of begin and start.

questions.question: I am not accustomed …………………. alone.
questions.description: After ‘be accustomed to’, we can use an infinitive or an –ing form.

questions.question: We are still waiting for them ……………..
questions.description: Some verbs are followed by for + object + infinitive. Wait is one of them. An –ing form is not usually possible in these cases.

questions.question: They are talking about ………………… to the country.
questions.description: We use an –ing form after a preposition.

questions.question: They repaired the roof instead ………………… on holiday.
I regret ……………….. my job. It was a big mistake.
questions.description: We use an -ing form after regret to refer to the past.
